overview.title: Car depreciation calculator
overview.content: The online calculator estimates the loss in value of a car by year, taking into account mileage, age and class. Linear and exponential depreciation methods are supported, as well as adjustments by mileage and vehicle segment.
overview.additionalContent: Depreciation depends on the brand, segment, market demand and technical condition. We use average market ratios suitable for preliminary estimates of residual value.

calculation.title: How is depreciation calculated?
calculation.content: Depreciation is the sum of the base annual loss of value by year and adjustments for mileage and segment. Linear and exponential methods are available.
calculation.formula: Residual value = Price × Π(1 − year_rate) × (1 − mileage_adjustment) × (1 − segment_adjustment)

advantages.title: Benefits of a depreciation calculator
advantages.content: A tool for quickly and visually assessing the residual value of a car.

tips.title: Tips for reducing losses
tips.content: How to reduce depreciation and maintain value:
tips.age: Look for cars 2–4 years old: the decline has already slowed down
tips.documentation: Keep a service history - this increases the price
tips.consultation: Compare by market and brands - premium loses faster

faqItems.q: How to calculate car depreciation?
faqItems.a: Use base rates by year and adjustments by mileage and segment. The calculator supports linear and exponential methods.

faqItems.q: What is the residual value of a car?
faqItems.a: This is an estimate of the current market price of a car, taking into account age, mileage and class.

faqItems.q: How does mileage affect depreciation?
faqItems.a: Over-mileage of approximately 15,000 km/year accelerates depreciation by 5–10% per year.

faqItems.q: What depreciation methods are supported?
faqItems.a: Linear (uniform decline) and exponential (more at the beginning, less later).

faqItems.q: What is the average annual loss in value?
faqItems.a: More often 10–15% per year after the first years, when the decline is higher (up to 18%).

faqItems.q: How much does a new car lose in the first year?
faqItems.a: On average, about 18% of the price, depending on the brand and segment.

faqItems.q: How are premium cars depreciated?
faqItems.a: Faster than market average: Add ~5% to base down rates.

faqItems.q: Does economy class lose less?
faqItems.a: Yes, as a rule, the fall is a little softer: −2% of base rates.

faqItems.q: How does brand affect liquidity?
faqItems.a: Strong brands support the price better: lower drops and faster sales.

faqItems.q: What is a depreciation schedule?
faqItems.a: This is a visualization of the car's price decline over the years.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to take into account repairs and accidents?
faqItems.a: Yes, significant accidents and paint damage reduce the price in addition to the base rates.

faqItems.q: What mileage is considered normal?
faqItems.a: The target is ~15,000 km/year. Strong deviations accelerate the fall.

faqItems.q: What is car depreciation?
faqItems.a: This is a decrease in market value over time due to wear and tear and market factors.

faqItems.q: How to calculate current value?
faqItems.a: Apply year-over-year decline rates and purchase price adjustments.

faqItems.q: How accurate are the calculations?
faqItems.a: These are indicative market estimates, accuracy depends on the specific vehicle.

faqItems.q: Does equipment count?
faqItems.a: Indirectly through the segment/brand. Over-staffing often degrades faster.

faqItems.q: Which method should you choose?
faqItems.a: For a new car, exponential is more realistic; for older cars, linear is more realistic.

faqItems.q: What is average annual depreciation?
faqItems.a: The average share of price reduction per year over the selected interval.

faqItems.q: How does seasonality affect?
faqItems.a: Crossovers in winter and convertibles in summer behave differently, which affects the price.

faqItems.q: What does liquidity depend on?
faqItems.a: From brand, history, condition, equipment and color. A good story increases the price.

faqItems.q: What is the residual price after 3 years?
faqItems.a: Estimated value with a typical decline of 35–45% over three years.

faqItems.q: How to take into account long runs?
faqItems.a: Add 5–10% to the drop for every ~10–15 thousand km above normal annually.

faqItems.q: Does maintenance at the dealer help?
faqItems.a: Yes, a proven service history increases residual value.

faqItems.q: Does the number of owners matter?
faqItems.a: Yes, many owners usually reduce the price and slow down the sale.

faqItems.q: How do restyles and generations affect?
faqItems.a: The release of a new generation accelerates the decline of the old model range.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to compare several cars?
faqItems.a: Yes, use the same parameters and compare the final costs.

faqItems.q: Is there a lower price limit?
faqItems.a: Yes, old cars tend to the market minimum for spare parts/export.

faqItems.q: Why does premium lose faster?
faqItems.a: A high price base, expensive service and narrow demand accelerate depreciation.

faqItems.q: Which calculation horizon is better?
faqItems.a: More often than not, 3–5 years is enough to plan a purchase/sale.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to export the calculation?
faqItems.a: Save the results as PDF/screenshot for discussion and comparison.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of calculating the cost of car ownership
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the cost of ownership for various types of cars:

example1.title: Example 1: Economy class car (5 years of ownership)
example1.description: Budget car with minimal expenses
example1.input:
Cost: 800,000 ₽
Tenure period: 5 years
Mileage: 20,000 km/year
Consumption: 8 l/100km
Fuel price: 55 ₽/l
OSAGO: 5,000 ₽/year
CASCO: 0 ₽
Transport tax: 2,000 ₽/year
Maintenance and repair: 20,000 ₽/year
Depreciation: 15%/year
example1.calculation:
Fuel per year: (20,000 / 100) × 8 × 55 = 88,000 ₽
Insurance per year: 5,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 2,000 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 20,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 800,000 × 0.15 = 120,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 88,000 + 5,000 + 2,000 + 20,000 + 120,000 = 235,000 RUR
Over 5 years: 235,000 × 5 = 1,175,000 ₽
Total cost of ownership: 800,000 + 1,175,000 = 1,975,000 RUR
Cost of 1 km: 1,975,000 / (20,000 × 5) = 19.75 ₽/km
example1.result: Total cost: 1,975,000 ₽ for 5 years, Cost of 1 km: 19.75 ₽
example1.note: Depreciation accounts for the largest share of expenses

example2.title: Example 2: Middle class (5 years of ownership)
example2.description: Mid-class car with moderate costs
example2.input:
Cost: 1,500,000 RUR
Tenure period: 5 years
Mileage: 25,000 km/year
Consumption: 10 l/100km
Fuel price: 55 ₽/l
OSAGO: 8,000 ₽/year
CASCO: 30,000 ₽/year
Transport tax: RUB 3,500/year
Maintenance and repair: 35,000 ₽/year
Depreciation: 12%/year
example2.calculation:
Fuel per year: (25,000 / 100) × 10 × 55 = 137,500 ₽
Insurance for the year: 8,000 + 30,000 = 38,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 3,500 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 35,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 1,500,000 × 0.12 = 180,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 137,500 + 38,000 + 3,500 + 35,000 + 180,000 = 394,000 RUR
Over 5 years: 394,000 × 5 = 1,970,000 ₽
Total cost of ownership: 1,500,000 + 1,970,000 = 3,470,000 RUR
Cost of 1 km: 3,470,000 / (25,000 × 5) = 27.76 ₽/km
example2.result: Total cost: 3,470,000 ₽ for 5 years, Cost of 1 km: 27.76 ₽

example3.title: Example 3: Premium car (5 years of ownership)
example3.description: Premium car with high expenses
example3.input:
Cost: 3,500,000 RUR
Tenure period: 5 years
Mileage: 30,000 km/year
Consumption: 12 l/100km
Fuel price: 55 ₽/l
OSAGO: 12,000 ₽/year
CASCO: 120,000 ₽/year
Transport tax: 8,000 ₽/year
Maintenance and repair: 80,000 ₽/year
Depreciation: 10%/year
example3.calculation:
Fuel per year: (30,000 / 100) × 12 × 55 = 198,000 ₽
Insurance for the year: 12,000 + 120,000 = 132,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 8,000 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 80,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 3,500,000 × 0.10 = 350,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 198,000 + 132,000 + 8,000 + 80,000 + 350,000 = 768,000 RUR
Over 5 years: 768,000 × 5 = 3,840,000 ₽
Total cost of ownership: 3,500,000 + 3,840,000 = 7,340,000 RUR
Cost of 1 km: 7,340,000 / (30,000 × 5) = 48.93 ₽/km
example3.result: Total cost: 7,340,000 ₽ for 5 years, Cost of 1 km: 48.93 ₽
example3.note: The high cost of CASCO and maintenance increases costs

example4.title: Example 4: Diesel car (5 years of ownership)
example4.description: Economical diesel car
example4.input:
Cost: 1,200,000 RUR
Tenure period: 5 years
Mileage: 30,000 km/year
Consumption: 6 l/100km (diesel)
Fuel price: 52 ₽/l (diesel)
OSAGO: 6,000 ₽/year
CASCO: 25,000 ₽/year
Transport tax: 2,500 ₽/year
Maintenance and repair: 30,000 ₽/year
Depreciation: 12%/year
example4.calculation:
Fuel per year: (30,000 / 100) × 6 × 52 = 93,600 ₽
Insurance for the year: 6,000 + 25,000 = 31,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 2,500 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 30,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 1,200,000 × 0.12 = 144,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 93,600 + 31,000 + 2,500 + 30,000 + 144,000 = 301,100 RUR
Over 5 years: 301,100 × 5 = 1,505,500 ₽
Total cost of ownership: 1,200,000 + 1,505,500 = 2,705,500 RUR
Cost of 1 km: 2,705,500 / (30,000 × 5) = 18.04 ₽/km
example4.result: Total cost: 2,705,500 ₽ for 5 years, Cost of 1 km: 18.04 ₽
example4.note: Low diesel consumption compensates for higher maintenance costs

example5.title: Example 5: Short tenure (3 years)
example5.input:
Cost: 1,500,000 RUR
Tenure period: 3 years
Mileage: 20,000 km/year
Consumption: 10 l/100km
Fuel price: 55 ₽/l

CASCO: 0 ₽

Maintenance and repair: 30,000 ₽/year
Depreciation: 18%/year (higher for short term)
example5.calculation:
Fuel per year: (20,000 / 100) × 10 × 55 = 110,000 ₽
Insurance per year: 8,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 3,500 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 30,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 1,500,000 × 0.18 = 270,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 110,000 + 8,000 + 3,500 + 30,000 + 270,000 = 421,500 RUR
For 3 years: 421,500 × 3 = 1,264,500 ₽
Total cost of ownership: 1,500,000 + 1,264,500 = 2,764,500 RUR
Cost of 1 km: 2,764,500 / (20,000 × 3) = 46.08 ₽/km
example5.result: Total cost: 2,764,500 ₽ for 3 years, Cost of 1 km: 46.08 ₽
example5.note: With a short period of time, depreciation is higher, which increases the cost of 1 km

example6.title: Example 6: Long tenure (7 years)
example6.input:
Cost: 800,000 ₽
Tenure period: 7 years
Mileage: 15,000 km/year
Consumption: 8 l/100km
Fuel price: 55 ₽/l
OSAGO: 5,000 ₽/year
CASCO: 0 ₽
Transport tax: 2,000 ₽/year
Maintenance and repairs: 25,000 ₽/year (increases over time)
Depreciation: 12%/year (lower for longer periods)
example6.calculation:
Fuel per year: (15,000 / 100) × 8 × 55 = 66,000 ₽
Insurance per year: 5,000 ₽
Taxes for the year: 2,000 ₽
Maintenance and repairs per year: 25,000 ₽
Depreciation for the year: 800,000 × 0.12 = 96,000 ₽

Annual expenses: 66,000 + 5,000 + 2,000 + 25,000 + 96,000 = 194,000 RUR
Over 7 years: 194,000 × 7 = 1,358,000 rubles
Total cost of ownership: 800,000 + 1,358,000 = 2,158,000 RUR

example6.result: Total cost: 2,158,000 ₽ for 7 years, Cost of 1 km: 20.55 ₽

faq.title: Frequently asked questions about the cost of ownership calculator

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of owning a car?
faqItems.a: The cost of ownership is calculated as the sum of all expenses for the period: purchase price + (annual expenses × number of years). Annual expenses include: fuel, insurance (MTPL, CASCO), transport tax, maintenance and repairs, depreciation. Our calculator automatically performs all calculations.

faqItems.q: What is included in the cost of owning a car?
faqItems.a: The cost of ownership includes: Purchase of a car (initial cost), Fuel (depending on mileage and consumption), Insurance (MTPL is mandatory, CASCO is optional), Transport tax (depending on power), Maintenance and repairs (regular maintenance), Depreciation (loss of value over time). All of these costs must be taken into account to truly estimate the cost of ownership.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel costs?
faqItems.a: Fuel costs are calculated: Fuel per year = (Mileage per year / 100) × Consumption (l/100km) × Price per liter. Example: mileage 20,000 km/year, consumption 10 l/100 km, price 55 ₽/l: Fuel = (20,000 / 100) × 10 × 55 = 110,000 ₽/year. For 5 years: 110,000 × 5 = 550,000 rubles.

faqItems.q: What is car depreciation?
faqItems.a: Depreciation is the loss in value of a vehicle over time due to wear, aging and obsolescence. Typically 10-18% of the cost per year. New cars lose more in the first years (up to 20-25%), then depreciation slows down. Depreciation is one of the largest expenses of owning a car.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of 1 km of car ownership?
faqItems.a: The cost of 1 km is calculated: Cost of 1 km = Total cost of ownership / (Annual mileage × Ownership period). Example: total cost 2,000,000 ₽ for 5 years, mileage 20,000 km/year: Cost 1 km = 2,000,000 / (20,000 × 5) = 20 ₽/km. This indicator helps to compare different cars.

faqItems.q: What expenses affect the cost of ownership the most?
faqItems.a: The greatest impact on the cost of ownership is exerted by: Depreciation (40-50% of total expenses), Fuel (20-30% of total expenses), Maintenance and repairs (10-20% of total expenses), Insurance (5-15% of total expenses), Taxes (2-5% of total expenses). Depreciation usually accounts for the largest share, especially in the early years.

faqItems.q: How to reduce the cost of owning a car?
faqItems.a: Ways to reduce the cost of ownership: Choose economical models (low fuel consumption), Regular maintenance (prevents costly breakdowns), Compare insurance (choose the best option), Buy cars with low depreciation (Japanese and German brands), Economical driving (reduces fuel consumption), Long tenure (reduces the cost of 1 km).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a year?
faqItems.a: Annual cost of ownership = Fuel for the year + Insurance for the year + Taxes for the year + Maintenance and repairs for the year + Depreciation for the year. Example: fuel 100,000 ₽, insurance 15,000 ₽, taxes 3,000 ₽, maintenance 25,000 ₽, depreciation 120,000 ₽: Annual cost = 100,000 + 15,000 + 3,000 + 25,000 + 120,000 = 263,000 ₽/year.

faqItems.q: Does the period of ownership affect the cost of 1 km?
faqItems.a: Yes, the period of ownership directly affects the cost of 1 km. With a short period (1-3 years), depreciation is higher, which increases the cost of 1 km. With a long term (5-10 years), the cost of 1 km decreases, since depreciation is distributed over a longer mileage. The optimal tenure for minimizing the cost of 1 km is 5-7 years.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership without CASCO?
faqItems.a: When calculating without CASCO, simply do not include the cost of CASCO in your annual expenses. Example: fuel 100,000 ₽, compulsory motor insurance 5,000 ₽, taxes 3,000 ₽, maintenance 25,000 ₽, depreciation 120,000 ₽ (without CASCO): Annual cost = 100,000 + 5,000 + 3,000 + 25,000 + 120 000 = 253,000 ₽/year. Savings: ~10,000-30,000 RUR/year.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a diesel car?
faqItems.a: For a diesel car, the calculation is similar, but take into account: Low consumption (usually 20-30% lower than gasoline), High price of diesel (usually 3-5 ₽/l higher), More expensive maintenance (diesel engines require more attention), Slower depreciation (diesels hold the price better). Example: consumption of 6 l/100km instead of 10 l/100km saves ~40% on fuel.

faqItems.q: What is TCO (Total Cost of Ownership)?
faqItems.a: TCO (Total Cost of Ownership) is the total cost of ownership, which includes all costs of purchasing, operating and maintaining a car for the entire period of ownership. TCO includes: purchase cost, fuel, insurance, taxes, maintenance and repairs, depreciation, additional expenses. TCO helps you get a realistic idea of ​​how much a car is actually worth.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a new car?
faqItems.a: For a new car, consider: High depreciation in the first years (20-25%/year), Warranty service (usually the first 3 years are cheaper), High cost of insurance (CASCO mandatory), Low repair costs (first years). Example: new car 2,000,000 ₽, depreciation 20%/year = 400,000 ₽/year only for depreciation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a used car?
faqItems.a: For a used car, consider: Low depreciation (5-10%/year), High repair costs (wear and tear increases), Possibility without CASCO (not always necessary), High maintenance costs (requires more attention). Example: used car 500,000 ₽, depreciation 8%/year = 40,000 ₽/year, but repairs can cost 50,000+ ₽/year.

faqItems.q: How to compare the cost of ownership of different cars?
faqItems.a: For comparison, calculate the cost of ownership for each car for the same period (for example, 5 years) and compare: Total cost of ownership, Cost per km, Annual costs, Share of each type of cost. A car with a lower cost per km for the same mileage is more economical. Also consider comfort, reliability and personal preference.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for an electric vehicle?
faqItems.a: For an electric car, the calculation is different: Energy consumption (kWh/100km) instead of fuel consumption, Charging cost (depending on the electricity tariff), Low maintenance costs (fewer parts), High depreciation in the first years, Transport tax benefits. Example: consumption 20 kWh/100 km, tariff 5 ₽/kWh: 20,000 km/year = 4,000 kWh × 5 ₽ = 20,000 ₽/year for charging (vs 110,000 ₽ for gasoline).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership taking into account the sale?
faqItems.a: When calculating taking into account the sale: Calculate the residual value through depreciation, Subtract the residual value from the total cost of ownership. Example: car 1,000,000 ₽, depreciation 12%/year, term 5 years: Residual value = 1,000,000 × (1 - 0.12)^5 = 527,731 ₽. Real Cost of Ownership = Total Cost - Residual Value. This is a more accurate indicator.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a hybrid car?
faqItems.a: For a hybrid car, consider: Low fuel consumption (usually 4-6 l/100 km), High purchase cost (more expensive than usual by RUB 200,000-500,000), High depreciation in the first years, Low maintenance costs (hybrid systems are reliable), Possible tax benefits. Hybrids are more profitable for high mileage (more than 30,000 km/year) due to fuel savings.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a car with LPG?
faqItems.a: For a car with LPG, consider: Cost of installing LPG (50,000-100,000 RUR), Gas consumption (usually 10-20% higher than gasoline), Low price of gas (2 times cheaper than gasoline), Additional costs for servicing LPG (5,000-10,000 RUR/year), Payback in 1-2 years with a mileage of more than 20,000 km/year. Example: savings on fuel of 50,000 ₽/year pay for the installation of gas equipment in 1-2 years.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership taking into account a loan or leasing?
faqItems.a: When calculating taking into account a loan/leasing, add: Loan interest (overpayment 10-30%), CASCO cost (usually mandatory), Down payment, Purchase price (for leasing). Example: loan of 1,500,000 rubles for 5 years at 12%: overpayment ~400,000 rubles. Credit/leasing increases the cost of ownership by 10-30%. Leasing can be more profitable for business due to tax benefits.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a premium car?
faqItems.a: For the premium class, consider: High cost of purchase, High cost of insurance (CASCO is mandatory, expensive), High cost of maintenance (official service is expensive), High depreciation (premium loses value faster), Additional costs (tires, accessories are more expensive). Premium cars have a cost of 1 km of 40-70 rubles due to high costs for all items.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a mid-class car?
faqItems.a: For the middle class, typical indicators: Purchase cost: 1,000,000-2,000,000 rubles, Annual expenses: 250,000-400,000 rubles, Cost of 1 km: 25-35 rubles. The middle class is optimal in terms of the ratio of comfort and cost of ownership. Middle-class cars have balanced costs in all respects.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for economy class?
faqItems.a: For economy class, typical indicators: Purchase cost: 600,000-1,000,000 rubles, Annual expenses: 150,000-250,000 rubles, Cost of 1 km: 18-25 rubles. Economy class has minimal costs but may require more attention to maintenance. Optimal for urban use with low mileage.

faqItems.q: How does mileage affect the cost of ownership?
faqItems.a: Mileage directly affects the cost of 1 km: High mileage (30,000+ km/year): high fuel and maintenance costs, high wear and tear, the cost of 1 km is higher. Low mileage (up to 10,000 km/year): low fuel costs, high share of fixed costs (insurance, taxes), the cost of 1 km is lower due to the distribution of depreciation. Optimal mileage is 15,000-25,000 km/year to balance costs.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a car without CASCO?
faqItems.a: When calculating without CASCO, the savings are 20,000-120,000 ₽/year, depending on the cost of the car. Risk: in case of an accident, repairs at your own expense. Example: car 1,500,000 ₽, CASCO 40,000 ₽/year: without CASCO the savings are 40,000 ₽/year, but in case of an accident the costs can be 200,000+ ₽. The decision depends on the risk and your willingness to repair at your own expense.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the optimal tenure to minimize the cost of 1 km?
faqItems.a: The optimal tenure for minimizing the cost of 1 km is usually 5-7 years. For a short period (1-3 years), high depreciation increases the cost of 1 km. With a long term (10+ years), repair costs increase, which also increases the cost. A period of 5-7 years is optimal: depreciation has already decreased, but repair costs are not yet critical.

faqItems.q: How to calculate cost of ownership for a new vs used car?
faqItems.a: Comparison of new and used: New car: high purchase cost, high depreciation, low repair costs (warranty), high insurance costs. Used: low purchase cost, low depreciation, high repair costs, low insurance costs. Typically, a used car has a lower cost per km with mileage over 15,000 km/year.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a car of different brands?
faqItems.a: Different brands have different cost of ownership: Japanese (Toyota, Honda): low depreciation, reliability, cost 1 km 18-25 ₽. German (BMW, Mercedes): high cost of maintenance, high depreciation in the first years, cost of 1 km 40-60 ₽. Korean (Hyundai, Kia): average cost of ownership, cost of 1 km 25-35 ₽. Domestic (Lada): low purchase cost, average costs, cost of 1 km 20-30 ₽.

faqItems.q: How does region affect cost of ownership?
faqItems.a: The region significantly influences the cost of ownership: Moscow/St. Petersburg: high parking costs (60,000-120,000 ₽/year), high parking fines, high transport tax, high prices for maintenance services. Regions: low parking costs, low fines, low transport tax, low prices for services. The difference in the cost of ownership between Moscow and the regions can be 50,000-100,000 ₽/year. Driving style also affects: aggressive driving increases costs by 15-25%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of ownership for a car, taking into account the sale at the end of the term?
faqItems.a: When calculating taking into account the sale: Calculate the residual value through depreciation, Subtract the sale price from the total cost of ownership, Get the real costs. Example: car 1,000,000 ₽, depreciation 12%/year, term 5 years, residual value 527,731 ₽. If sold for 500,000 ₽: real costs = Total cost - 500,000. This is a more accurate indicator of the cost of ownership. Different types of cars (sedan, crossover, SUV) have different prices for 1 km: from 25 to 60 rubles.

calculation.title: How is OSAGO calculated?
calculation.content: Calculation of the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance is based on a formula approved by the Central Bank of the Russian Federation, taking into account all existing coefficients.
calculation.formula: Cost = Base rate × CT × KBM × KVS × KM × KO
calculation.baseRate: Base rate: 5,000 rubles (set by the Central Bank of the Russian Federation)
calculation.coefficients: Coefficients: CT (territory), KBM (bonus-malus), KVS (age-experience), KM (power), KO (limitation)

coefficients.title: OSAGO calculation coefficients
coefficients.content: The cost of compulsory motor liability insurance is calculated using the formula: Basic tariff × CT × KBM × KVS × KM × KO
coefficients.territory: CT (territory coefficient): Moscow = 2.0, St. Petersburg = 1.8, other regions = 1.0
coefficients.ageExperience: KVS (age-experience): age < 22 and experience < 3 years = 1.8, otherwise = 1.0
coefficients.bonusMalus: KBM (bonus-malus): from 0.5 to 2.45 depending on driving history

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: The cost of compulsory motor liability insurance is calculated using the formula: Base rate × CT × KBM × KVS × KM × KO. The base rate is 5,000 rubles. Use our calculator by entering the region, engine power, driver age and experience, number of drivers and bonus-malus coefficient.

faqItems.q: What coefficients affect the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: The cost of compulsory motor insurance is affected by 5 coefficients: CT (territory) - from 1.0 to 2.0, KBM (bonus-malus) - from 0.5 to 2.45, KVS (age-experience) - 1.0 or 1.8, KM (power) - from 0.6 to 1.4, KO (driver limitation) - from 1.0 to 1.8. Each factor can significantly change the final cost.

faqItems.q: What is the bonus-malus ratio (BMR)?
faqItems.a: KBM is a coefficient that depends on the driver’s driving history. With accident-free driving, the KBM decreases from 1.0 to 0.5 (maximum discount of 50%). In case of accidents, the KBM increases to 2.45 (145% increase). The KBM remains the same when changing insurance companies.

faqItems.q: What is the territorial coefficient (CT) in Moscow and St. Petersburg?
faqItems.a: In Moscow, CT = 2.0 (the highest), in St. Petersburg, CT = 1.8, in other regions, CT = 1.0. The territorial coefficient reflects accident statistics in the region and affects the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance.

faqItems.q: How do age and length of service affect the cost of compulsory motor insurance?
faqItems.a: FAC coefficient = 1.8 for drivers under 22 years of age with less than 3 years of experience, otherwise FAC = 1.0. Young, inexperienced drivers pay 80% more for compulsory motor insurance. Experience is counted from the moment you receive your first driver's license.

faqItems.q: How does engine power affect the cost of compulsory motor insurance?
faqItems.a: The KM coefficient depends on the power: up to 70 hp. = 0.6, 70-100 hp = 1.0, 101-120 hp = 1.1, 121-150 hp = 1.2, over 150 hp = 1.4. The more powerful the car, the higher the cost of compulsory motor insurance.

faqItems.q: What is more profitable: one driver or an unlimited list?
faqItems.a: One driver (KO = 1.0) is the cheapest option. Multiple drivers (CP = 1.2) increases the cost by 20%. Unlimited list (KO = 1.8) increases the cost by 80%. Choose a minimal list if possible.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to change the BMR when changing insurance companies?
faqItems.a: No, the KBM is tied to the driver and remains the same when changing insurance companies. Data on KBM are stored in a single database of RSA (Russian Union of Auto Insurers) and are available to all insurance companies.

faqItems.q: How can I find out my current KBM?
faqItems.a: The KBM can be found on the RSA website by entering the driver and vehicle data. KBM is also indicated in the previous OSAGO policy. When registering for the first time, OSAGO KBM = 1.0 (basic tariff).

faqItems.q: What to do if the KBM is calculated incorrectly?
faqItems.a: If the BMR is calculated incorrectly, contact the insurance company with a request for recalculation. If necessary, file a complaint with the RSA or the Central Bank of the Russian Federation. An incorrect KBM can lead to overpayment or underpayment under compulsory motor liability insurance.

faqItems.q: Is it necessary to apply for compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: Yes, OSAGO is mandatory for all car owners in Russia. Driving a car without a valid MTPL policy will result in a fine of 800 rubles and a ban on operating the vehicle until the policy is issued.

faqItems.q: When do you need to renew OSAGO?
faqItems.a: OSAGO is issued for 1 year and is renewed annually. It is recommended to renew 1-2 months before the expiration date to maintain the current BMR and avoid cost increases.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to apply for compulsory motor liability insurance online?
faqItems.a: Yes, most insurance companies offer OSAGO registration online. It's convenient, fast and often cheaper than in the office. For registration you need scans of documents and an electronic signature.

faqItems.q: What documents are needed to apply for compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: To apply for compulsory motor liability insurance you need: driver’s passport, driver’s license, vehicle title or vehicle registration certificate, diagnostic card (if required), previous compulsory motor liability insurance policy (to determine the vehicle liability insurance). For legal entities, constituent documents are additionally required.

faqItems.q: What is a diagnostic card and is it needed?
faqItems.a: A diagnostic card is a document confirming the completion of a technical inspection. It is needed for cars older than 4 years. Without a valid diagnostic card, you cannot apply for compulsory motor liability insurance. The card is valid for 1 year for new cars, 6 months for old ones.

faqItems.q: How to save on compulsory motor insurance?
faqItems.a: Ways to save: 1) Maintain a good KBM by accident-free driving. 2) Limit the list of drivers. 3) Choose a car with less power. 4) Compare offers from different insurance companies. 5) Renew your policy in advance.

faqItems.q: What to do in case of an accident under compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: In case of an accident: 1) Call the traffic police and an ambulance (if there are victims). 2) Record the circumstances of the accident. 3) Contact the culprit’s insurance company within 5 days. 4) Provide all necessary documents. 5) Get damages.

faqItems.q: How much is the payment limit for compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: Limit of payments under compulsory motor liability insurance: up to 400,000 rubles for damage to property, up to 500,000 rubles for harm to the life and health of the victim. If damage is caused to several victims, the limit increases in proportion to the number of victims.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to return OSAGO when selling a car?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can return part of the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance if the contract is terminated early. The refund is calculated in proportion to the unused period. Contact the insurance company with an application and documents to deregister the car.

faqItems.q: What is a franchise under OSAGO?
faqItems.a: The deductible is the part of the damage that is reimbursed by the policyholder himself. Under compulsory motor liability insurance, a deductible does not apply - the insurer compensates for all damage within the limit. The deductible can only be applied under CASCO insurance.

faqItems.q: How to check the authenticity of an MTPL policy?
faqItems.a: You can check the authenticity of the policy on the RSA website by entering the series and policy number. You can also check through the insurance company’s mobile application or by contacting the insurer’s office. Fake policies are invalid and will result in penalties.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to issue MTPL for several months?
faqItems.a: No, OSAGO is issued only for 1 year. An exception is a temporary policy for 20 days when purchasing a car, but it costs more and does not replace the main policy. A temporary policy is needed to move a car.

faqItems.q: What is an electronic MTPL policy?
faqItems.a: An electronic OSAGO policy is a policy in electronic form, equivalent to a paper one. It is stored in the insurance company's database and is accessible through a mobile application. An electronic policy is more convenient and environmentally friendly than a paper one.

faqItems.q: How have MTPL tariffs changed in 2024?
faqItems.a: In 2024, the base MTPL rate is 5,000 rubles (no changes from 2023). Some territorial coefficients and rules for calculating KBM have changed. It is recommended to recalculate the cost of compulsory motor liability insurance taking into account the new tariffs.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to apply for compulsory motor liability insurance without a technical inspection?
faqItems.a: No, to apply for compulsory motor liability insurance you need a valid diagnostic card (technical inspection). An exception is cars under 4 years old, for which inspection is not required. Without a technical inspection, the MTPL policy is invalid.

faqItems.q: What to do if you have lost your MTPL policy?
faqItems.a: If you lose your MTPL policy, contact your insurance company for a duplicate. A duplicate is issued free of charge upon presentation of your passport. Until you receive a duplicate, you can drive the car with your insurance documents.

faqItems.q: How to calculate compulsory motor liability insurance for a taxi?
faqItems.a: Increased MTPL tariffs apply for taxis. The taxi coefficient is 1.6-2.0 depending on the region. The remaining coefficients are calculated as standard. The cost of MTPL for a taxi is much higher than usual.

faqItems.q: What to do if the insurance company refuses to pay?
faqItems.a: If payment is refused: 1) Receive a written refusal with justification. 2) Contact the RSA with a complaint. 3) File a lawsuit. 4) Contact the Central Bank of the Russian Federation. 5) Engage an independent expert to assess the damage.

faqItems.q: What is CASCO and how is it different from OSAGO?
faqItems.a: CASCO is voluntary car insurance against damage and theft. OSAGO - compulsory insurance of liability to third parties. CASCO protects your car, OSAGO protects other road users. CASCO is 5-10 times more expensive than OSAGO.

faqItems.q: Is the OSAGO calculator free?
faqItems.a: Yes, the OSAGO calculator is completely free and does not require registration. You can use it an unlimited number of times to calculate the cost of a policy with any parameters. The calculator works online, does not require installation of programs and is available 24/7. All functions, including calculations for various regions and scenarios, are provided free of charge.

calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the cost of CASCO for various situations:

example1.title: Example 1: New car 2,000,000 ₽, experienced driver
example1.description: Premium car in Moscow with an experienced driver and alarm system
example1.input:
Cost: 2,000,000 ₽
Year: 2024
Age: 35 years, experience 15 years
Region: Moscow (Region = 1.2)
Alarm: yes (Kalarm = 0.9)
Franchise: no franchise (Kfranchise = 1.0)
example1.calculation:
Base rate: 6%
Kregion × Kvozrast × Kstazh × Ksignalization × Kfranchise = 1.2 × 1.0 × 1.0 × 0.9 × 1.0 = 1.08
Cost: 2,000,000 × 0.06 × 1.08 = 129,600 ₽
example1.note: An experienced driver with an alarm receives minimal odds

example2.title: Example 2: Young driver, 1,500,000 ₽

example2.calculation:
Base rate: 6%
Kregion × Kvozrast × Kstazh × Ksignalization × Kfranchise = 1.1 × 1.2 × 1.3 × 1.0 × 0.9 = 1.544
Cost: 1,500,000 × 0.06 × 1.544 = 138,960 ₽
example2.note: High age and experience factors increase cost

example3.note: A deductible of 20,000 ₽ significantly reduces the cost of the policy

example4.note: The high cost of the car is compensated by minimal coefficients

example5.input:

Year: 2015
Age: 20 years, experience 1 year
Region: Other regions (Region = 1.0)
Alarm: no (Kalarm = 1.0)
Franchise: 10,000 ₽ (Cfranchise = 0.9)
example5.calculation:
Base rate: 6%
Kregion × Kvozrast × Kstazh × Ksignalization × Kfranchise = 1.0 × 1.5 × 1.3 × 1.0 × 0.9 = 1.755
Cost: 600,000 × 0.06 × 1.755 = 63,180 ₽
example5.note: High coefficients of age and experience increase the cost by 1.75 times

example6.title: Example 6: Middle class 1,200,000 ₽, optimal conditions
example6.description: Middle class car with optimal insurance conditions
example6.input:
Cost: 1,200,000 RUR
Year: 2021
Age: 32 years, experience 12 years
Region: St. Petersburg (Region = 1.1)
Alarm: yes (Kalarm = 0.9)
Franchise: 10,000 ₽ (Cfranchise = 0.9)
example6.calculation:
Base rate: 6%
Kregion × Kvozrast × Kstazh × Ksignalization × Kfranchise = 1.1 × 1.0 × 1.0 × 0.9 × 0.9 = 0.891
Cost: 1,200,000 × 0.06 × 0.891 = 64,152 ₽
example6.note: An experienced driver with an alarm and a franchise receives a minimum cost

calculation.title: How is CASCO calculated?
calculation.content: Calculation of the cost of CASCO is based on a formula taking into account all existing coefficients and risk factors.
calculation.formula: Cost = (Cost of the car × Base rate) × Kregion × Age × Term × Alarm × Franchise
calculation.baseRate: Base rate: 6% of the cost of the car (set by the insurance company)
calculation.coefficients: Coefficients: Kregion (region), Age (age), Kstazh (experience), Ksignalization (alarm), Kfranchise (franchise)

coefficients.title: CASCO calculation coefficients
coefficients.content: The cost of CASCO is calculated using the formula: (Cost of the car × Base rate) × Kregion × Age × Service × Alarm system × Franchise
coefficients.region: Region: Moscow = 1.2, St. Petersburg = 1.1, other regions = 1.0
coefficients.age: Age: under 22 years old = 1.5, 22-30 years old = 1.2, over 30 years old = 1.0
coefficients.experience: By the way: up to 3 years = 1.3, 3-10 years = 1.1, more than 10 years = 1.0

advantages.title: Advantages of using the CASCO calculator
advantages.content: The CASCO calculator provides many advantages for planning car insurance:
advantages.comprehensive: Full coverage of damage from any risks: accident, theft, theft, natural disasters
advantages.quick: Quick and accurate calculation of the cost of the policy in a few minutes without contacting the insurance company
advantages.accurate: Accurate calculation taking into account all current coefficients and risk factors
advantages.comparison: Possibility to compare the cost of CASCO insurance in different insurance companies to choose the best option

tips.title: Tips for choosing CASCO insurance
tips.content: To choose the optimal CASCO policy:
tips.compare: Compare offers from different insurance companies - the cost may differ by 30-50%. Use the calculator for an accurate comparison
tips.alarm: Install an anti-theft system - this reduces the cost of CASCO by 10% and protects the car from theft
tips.franchise: Consider a deductible to reduce the cost of your policy. A franchise of 20,000 ₽ reduces the cost by 20%
tips.documents: Prepare all necessary documents in advance: passport, driver’s license, PTS, diagnostic card

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of CASCO?
faqItems.a: The cost of CASCO is calculated using the formula: (Cost of the car × 6%) × Kregion × Kvozrast × Kstazh × Ksalizatsiya × Franchise. Use our calculator by entering the cost of the car, year of manufacture, age and experience of the driver, region, presence of an alarm system and the franchise amount.

faqItems.q: What coefficients affect the cost of CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: The cost of CASCO is affected by 5 coefficients: Kregion (1.0-1.2) - depends on the region, Age (1.0-1.5) - depends on the age of the driver, Experience (1.0-1.3) - depends on driving experience, KAlarm (0.9-1.0) - depends on the presence of an alarm, Kfranchise (0.8-1.0) - depends on the size of the franchise.

faqItems.q: What is a CASCO franchise?
faqItems.a: The deductible is the part of the damage that the policyholder himself compensates when an insured event occurs. A deductible of 10,000 ₽ means that for damage up to 10,000 ₽ you pay yourself, and above that the insurance company pays. The franchise reduces the cost of CASCO by 10-20%.

faqItems.q: What is the regional coefficient in Moscow and St. Petersburg?
faqItems.a: In Moscow Kregion = 1.2 (the highest), in St. Petersburg Kregion = 1.1, in other regions Kregion = 1.0. The regional coefficient reflects the statistics of accidents and thefts in the region.

faqItems.q: How does the driver's age affect the cost of CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: Age coefficient: under 22 years old = 1.5, 22-30 years old = 1.2, over 30 years old = 1.0. Young drivers are considered riskier and pay more for CASCO insurance.

faqItems.q: How does driving experience affect the cost of CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: Coefficient of experience: up to 3 years = 1.3, 3-10 years = 1.1, more than 10 years = 1.0. Inexperienced drivers are more likely to get into accidents, so they pay more for insurance.

faqItems.q: How does an alarm affect the cost of CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: The presence of an anti-theft system reduces the cost of CASCO insurance by 10% (Kalarm = 0.9). The alarm system protects the car from theft and theft, so insurance companies provide a discount. No alarm KAlarm = 1.0.

faqItems.q: What is more profitable: CASCO or OSAGO?
faqItems.a: CASCO and OSAGO are different types of insurance. OSAGO is mandatory and covers damage to third parties. CASCO is voluntary and covers damage to your car. CASCO is 5-10 times more expensive than OSAGO, but provides complete protection for the car.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to get CASCO insurance without compulsory motor liability insurance?
faqItems.a: No, to apply for CASCO insurance, you must have a valid MTPL policy. OSAGO is compulsory insurance; you cannot drive a car without it. CASCO is an additional protection that is issued on top of compulsory motor liability insurance.

faqItems.q: What risks does CASCO cover?
faqItems.a: CASCO covers: road accidents (accidents), car theft, theft, natural disasters (hurricane, flood, hail), illegal actions of third parties (vandalism, arson), falling objects on the car. The full list of risks is specified in the insurance contract.

faqItems.q: Is it necessary to apply for CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: No, CASCO is voluntary insurance. Unlike MTPL, CASCO is not mandatory. However, CASCO is recommended for expensive cars, as it provides complete protection against all risks and can save significant amounts in the event of an insured event.

faqItems.q: When do you need to renew CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: CASCO is issued for 1 year and is renewed annually. It is recommended to renew 1-2 months before the expiration date to avoid a gap in coverage. If there is a break in insurance, the coefficients may change.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to apply for CASCO insurance online?
faqItems.a: Yes, most insurance companies offer CASCO registration online. It's convenient, fast and often cheaper than in the office. For registration you need scans of documents, photographs of the car and an electronic signature.

faqItems.q: What documents are needed to apply for CASCO insurance?
faqItems.a: To apply for CASCO you need: a driver’s passport, a driver’s license, a vehicle’s title or vehicle registration certificate, a diagnostic card, an MTPL policy, a certificate of the value of the car (for expensive cars), photographs of the car. For legal entities, constituent documents are additionally required.

faqItems.q: How to save on CASCO?
faqItems.a: Ways to save: 1) Install an alarm system - 10% discount. 2) Choose a franchise - 10-20% discount. 3) Compare offers from different insurance companies. 4) Renew your policy in advance. 5) Choose a car with a lower cost. 6) Increase your driving experience.

faqItems.q: What to do in case of an accident under CASCO?
faqItems.a: In case of an accident under CASCO: 1) Call the traffic police and an ambulance (if there are victims). 2) Record the circumstances of the accident. 3) Contact the insurance company within 5 days. 4) Provide all necessary documents. 5) Get compensation for damage or a referral for repairs.

faqItems.q: How much is the payment limit for CASCO?
faqItems.a: The limit of payments under CASCO is equal to the value of the car at the time of insurance. In case of total loss of the vehicle, the full price is paid. In case of partial damage - the cost of repair. The limit may be limited by the wear and tear of the car (usually no more than 80% of the cost).

faqItems.q: Is it possible to return CASCO when selling a car?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can return part of the CASCO cost if you terminate the contract early. The refund is calculated in proportion to the unused period. Contact the insurance company with an application and documents to deregister the car.

faqItems.q: What is wear and tear under CASCO?
faqItems.a: Depreciation is the decrease in value of a vehicle due to use. When calculating the CASCO payment, depreciation is taken into account: for cars up to 2 years old - 0%, 2-5 years - 5% per year, 5-10 years - 10% per year, over 10 years - 15% per year. Depreciation cannot exceed 80% of the cost.

faqItems.q: How to check the authenticity of a CASCO policy?
faqItems.a: You can check the authenticity of the policy on the insurance company's website by entering the series and policy number. You can also check through the insurer's mobile application or by contacting the office. Fake policies are invalid and will result in penalties.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to get CASCO insurance for several months?
faqItems.a: No, CASCO is issued only for 1 year. An exception is a temporary policy for 20 days when purchasing a car, but it costs more and does not replace the main policy. A temporary policy is needed to move a car.

faqItems.q: What is an electronic CASCO policy?
faqItems.a: An electronic CASCO policy is a policy in electronic form, equivalent to a paper one. It is stored in the insurance company's database and is accessible through a mobile application. An electronic policy is more convenient and environmentally friendly than a paper one.

faqItems.q: How have CASCO tariffs changed in 2024?
faqItems.a: In 2024, the base CASCO rate is 6% of the cost of the car (no changes from 2023). Some regional coefficients and rules for calculating wear have changed. It is recommended to recalculate the cost of CASCO insurance taking into account the new tariffs.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to apply for CASCO insurance without a technical inspection?
faqItems.a: No, to apply for CASCO you need a valid diagnostic card (technical inspection). An exception is cars under 4 years old, for which inspection is not required. Without a technical inspection, the CASCO policy is invalid.

faqItems.q: What to do if you have lost your CASCO policy?
faqItems.a: If you lose your CASCO policy, contact your insurance company for a duplicate. A duplicate is issued free of charge upon presentation of your passport. Until you receive a duplicate, you can drive the car with your insurance documents.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to get CASCO insurance for a car without a title?
faqItems.a: No, to apply for CASCO you definitely need a PTS (vehicle passport) or STS (registration certificate). Without these documents, a CASCO policy cannot be issued. The PTS must be original, not a copy.

faqItems.q: What is CASCO+ and how is it different from regular insurance?
faqItems.a: CASCO+ is an expanded version of CASCO with additional services: evacuation, replacement car, legal assistance, 24-hour support. The cost of CASCO+ is 20-30% higher than usual, but includes more services.

faqItems.q: What to do if the insurance company refuses to pay?
faqItems.a: If payment is refused: 1) Receive a written refusal with justification. 2) Contact the RSA with a complaint. 3) File a lawsuit. 4) Contact the Central Bank of the Russian Federation. 5) Engage an independent expert to assess the damage.

faqItems.q: Is the CASCO calculator free?
faqItems.a: Yes, the CASCO calculator is completely free and does not require registration. You can use it an unlimited number of times to calculate the cost of a policy with any parameters. The calculator works online, does not require installation of programs and is available 24/7. All functions, including calculations for various regions and scenarios, are provided free of charge.

faqItems.q: How often are CASCO tariffs updated?
faqItems.a: CASCO rates may be changed by insurance companies depending on the market situation, accident statistics and other factors. Base rates are usually revised 1-2 times a year. It is recommended that you check the current rates before taking out a policy as they may vary between insurance companies. The calculator uses average market rates for preliminary calculations.

overview.title: Fuel consumption calculator for trip planning
overview.content: An online fuel consumption calculator will help you calculate how many kilometers you can drive on a given amount of fuel, or how many liters of fuel will be required to travel the required distance with a known car consumption. The calculator takes into account the actual fuel consumption of your car and allows you to accurately plan trips, routes and fuel budgets.
overview.additionalContent: Fuel consumption is one of the most important parameters when operating a car. Knowing the exact consumption helps plan trips, calculate the cost of travel and control the efficiency of the car. The calculator works in two modes: distance calculation (how far you can travel on the available fuel) and fuel calculation (how much is needed to travel a given distance). Both calculations are based on simple mathematical formulas taking into account the car's consumption in liters per 100 kilometers.

averageConsumptionByType.title: Average fuel consumption by car type

distanceComparison.title: Distance with different fuel volumes (consumption 8.5 l/100 km)

calculationExamples.title: Examples of fuel consumption calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculations for various scenarios of using the calculator:

example1.title: Example 1: Distance calculation - city car
example1.description: Small car with a consumption of 7.5 l/100 km, a full tank of 45 liters
example1.input:
Fuel consumption: 7.5 l/100km
Fuel quantity: 45 l
Mode: Distance calculation
example1.calculation:
Formula: Distance = (Amount of fuel / Consumption) × 100
Distance = (45 / 7.5) × 100
Distance = 6 × 100 = 600 km
On a full tank (45 l) you can drive 600 km
example1.note: Economical cars allow you to travel long distances on a small amount of fuel.

example2.title: Example 2: Calculating fuel for a trip - middle class
example2.description: A middle class car with a consumption of 9.2 l/100 km, you need to drive 850 km
example2.input:
Fuel consumption: 9.2 l/100km
Distance: 850 km
Mode: Fuel calculation
example2.calculation:
Formula: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100
Fuel = (9.2 × 850) / 100
Fuel = 7820 / 100 = 78.2 l
For a trip of 850 km you will need 78.2 liters of fuel
example2.note: For long trips it is important to calculate the exact amount of fuel with a reserve

example3.title: Example 3: Distance calculation - crossover
example3.description: Crossover with a consumption of 11.5 l/100 km, 55 liters in the tank
example3.input:
Fuel consumption: 11.5 l/100km
Fuel quantity: 55 l
Mode: Distance calculation
example3.calculation:
Formula: Distance = (55 / 11.5) × 100
Distance = 4.783 × 100 = 478.3 km
On 55 liters of fuel you can travel ~478 km
example3.note: Crossovers have higher consumption, but also a larger tank volume to compensate

example4.title: Example 4: Fuel calculation - SUV
example4.description: SUV with a consumption of 14.8 l/100 km, a trip of 600 km is planned
example4.input:
Fuel consumption: 14.8 l/100km
Distance: 600 km
Mode: Fuel calculation
example4.calculation:
Formula: Fuel = (14.8 × 600) / 100
Fuel = 8880 / 100 = 88.8 l
The trip will require 88.8 liters of fuel (almost 2 tanks)
example4.note: SUVs consume a lot of fuel, it is important to plan refueling in advance

example5.title: Example 5: Distance calculation - diesel car
example5.description: Diesel sedan with a consumption of 5.8 l/100 km, a tank of 60 liters
example5.input:
Fuel consumption: 5.8 l/100km
Fuel quantity: 60 l
Mode: Distance calculation
example5.calculation:
Formula: Distance = (60 / 5.8) × 100
Distance = 10.345 × 100 = 1034.5 km
The diesel engine allows you to travel more than 1000 km on a full tank
example5.note: Diesel engines are more economical than gasoline engines, allowing you to travel more with the same volume.

example6.title: Example 6: Fuel calculation - long trip
example6.description: A car with a consumption of 8.5 l/100 km, a trip is planned from Moscow to Sochi (1500 km)
example6.input:
Fuel consumption: 8.5 l/100km
Distance: 1500 km
Mode: Fuel calculation
example6.calculation:
Formula: Fuel = (8.5 × 1500) / 100
Fuel = 12750 / 100 = 127.5 l
The trip will require 127.5 liters of fuel
Taking into account a 60 l tank: 127.5 / 60 = 2.13 tanks
You will need to refuel at least 2 times
example6.note: For long trips, it is important to calculate the number of gas stations and plan the route

advantages.content: The fuel consumption calculator provides many benefits:

advantages.accurate: Accurate calculations based on the actual consumption of your car and specified parameters

tips.title: Fuel Saving Tips
tips.content: To reduce fuel consumption and optimize your trips, follow our recommendations:
tips.measurement: Regularly measure your vehicle's fuel consumption for accurate planning. Use the method: fill up a full tank, reset the meter, drive a certain distance, fill up again and divide the amount of fill by the distance traveled. Keep a fuel log to track changes
tips.driving: Maintain a smooth driving style without sudden acceleration or braking. Do not exceed the optimal speed of 80-90 km/h on the highway for minimum consumption. Turn off the engine during long stops (more than 2 minutes)
tips.maintenance: Monitor your tire pressure - reduced pressure increases fuel consumption by 3-5%. Change the air and fuel filters regularly. Monitor the technical condition of the engine and undergo maintenance on time
tips.planning: Plan your routes in advance to avoid traffic jams and detours. Do not overload the car - every extra 100 kg increases consumption by 0.5-1 l/100km. Use air conditioner sparingly - it increases consumption by 5-15%

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption?
faqItems.a: Fuel consumption is calculated as follows: fill a full tank, reset the odometer, drive 100-200 km, fill the full tank again and divide the filling volume by the distance traveled, then multiply by 100. Formula: Consumption (l/100km) = (Filling volume (l) / Mileage (km)) × 100. Example: filled 15 l, drove 200 km: Consumption = (15 / 200) × 100 = 7.5 l/100km.

faqItems.q: How far can you travel on 10 liters of gasoline?
faqItems.a: Depends on the car's consumption. Formula: Distance = (Amount of fuel / Consumption) × 100. Examples: With a consumption of 7 l/100 km: (10 / 7) × 100 = 143 km. At a consumption of 10 l/100 km: (10 / 10) × 100 = 100 km. At a consumption of 12 l/100 km: (10 / 12) × 100 = 83 km. The lower the consumption, the longer the distance with the same amount of fuel.

faqItems.q: How to calculate how many liters of fuel you need for a trip?
faqItems.a: Use the formula: Fuel (l) = (Consumption (l/100km) × Distance (km)) / 100. Example: consumption 9 l/100km, trip 500 km: Fuel = (9 × 500) / 100 = 45 l. It is recommended to take a reserve of 10-15% for unforeseen situations. For a trip of 500 km, it is better to plan 50 liters of fuel.

faqItems.q: What is normal fuel consumption for a car?
faqItems.a: Normal consumption depends on the type and class of the car: Small car (1.0-1.6 l): 6-8 l/100km in the city, 5-7 l/100km on the highway. Middle class (1.6-2.5 l): 8-11 l/100km in the city, 7-9 l/100km on the highway. Crossover (2.0-3.0 l): 10-13 l/100km in the city, 8-11 l/100km on the highway. SUV (2.5-5.0 l): 12-18 l/100km in the city, 10-15 l/100km on the highway.

faqItems.q: Why has fuel consumption increased?
faqItems.a: Reasons for increased consumption: 1) Reduced tire pressure (increases consumption by 3-5%), 2) Dirty filters (air, fuel), 3) Malfunction of sensors (oxygen sensor, flow meter), 4) Wear of spark plugs, 5) Problems with the cooling system, 6) Vehicle overload, 7) Aggressive driving style, 8) Traffic jams and frequent stops, 9) Using air conditioning.

faqItems.q: How to reduce fuel consumption?
faqItems.a: Ways to reduce consumption: 1) Maintain the correct tire pressure (according to the manufacturer's instructions), 2) Use high-quality fuel of the recommended brand, 3) Accelerate and brake smoothly, avoid sudden maneuvers, 4) Do not overload the car - remove excess luggage, 5) Regularly undergo maintenance (replacing filters, spark plugs), 6) Plan routes avoiding traffic jams, 7) Use cruise control when highway, 8) Turn off the air conditioning at low temperatures, 9) Do not warm up the engine for a long time - 30-60 seconds is enough.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between consumption in the city and on the highway?
faqItems.a: In the city, consumption is higher due to frequent stops, accelerations, traffic jams and low speeds. On the highway, consumption is lower due to constant speed, rare stops and optimal conditions. Typically the difference is 20-40%. Example: a car with a consumption of 8 l/100 km on the highway will consume 10-11 l/100 km in the city. The mixed cycle (city + highway) is usually in the middle.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of fuel for a trip?
faqItems.a: First calculate the amount of fuel: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100. Then multiply by the price per liter: Cost = Fuel × Price per liter. Example: consumption 9 l/100 km, trip 600 km, price 55 ₽/l: Fuel = (9 × 600) / 100 = 54 l, Cost = 54 × 55 = 2970 ₽. Add 10-15% margin for reliability: 2970 × 1.1 = 3267 ₽.

faqItems.q: What is a mixed fuel cycle?
faqItems.a: Combined cycle is the average fuel consumption for a combination of city and country driving (usually 60% city, 40% highway). Manufacturers indicate consumption in three modes: urban (WLTP city), suburban (WLTP highway) and mixed (WLTP combined). The combined cycle most accurately reflects actual consumption for most drivers. Formula: Mixed = (Urban × 0.6) + (Highway × 0.4).

faqItems.q: How to check the real fuel consumption of a car?
faqItems.a: Test method: 1) Fill the tank full before the gun rebounds, 2) Reset the mileage counter or record the current one, 3) Drive 100-300 km in normal mode, 4) Fill the tank full again before the gun rebounds, record the filling volume and mileage, 5) Calculate: Consumption = (Filling volume / Mileage) × 100. Repeat 2-3 times for accuracy. Average the results. Keep a log to track changes.

faqItems.q: How many liters are in a full tank for different cars?
faqItems.a: The volume of the fuel tank depends on the class of the car: Small cars: 35-45 l (Renault Logan - 50 l, Lada Granta - 43 l). Middle class: 50-65 l (Toyota Camry - 60 l, Volkswagen Passat - 66 l). Crossovers: 55-70 l (Hyundai Creta - 50 l, Kia Sportage - 58 l, Toyota RAV4 - 60 l). SUVs: 70-100 l (Toyota Land Cruiser - 93 l, Nissan Patrol - 98 l). Minibuses: 75-100 l (Mercedes Sprinter - 75 l, Ford Transit - 80 l).

faqItems.q: How to calculate how many times you need to refuel on a trip?
faqItems.a: Calculation of refills: 1) Calculate the required fuel: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100, 2) Divide by tank volume: Refills = Fuel / Tank volume, round up, 3) Add a margin of 10-15%. Example: trip 1200 km, consumption 9 l/100 km, tank 60 l: Fuel = (9 × 1200) / 100 = 108 l, Refills = 108 / 60 = 1.8 ≈ 2 times, With reserve = 3 refills. The first refueling is a full tank before the trip, then refueling every ~400-500 km.

faqItems.q: What fuel consumption is considered economical?
faqItems.a: Consumption is considered economical: Small cars: up to 7 l/100 km. Middle class: up to 9 l/100 km. Crossovers: up to 11 l/100 km. SUVs: up to 15 l/100km. Diesel engines are usually 20-30% more economical than gasoline engines. Hybrid cars have a consumption of 4-6 l/100 km (including the electric motor). Electric cars do not consume fuel, but have an energy consumption in kWh/100km. Economy depends on driving style, operating conditions and technical condition.

faqItems.q: Does fuel quality affect consumption?
faqItems.a: Yes, fuel quality affects engine consumption and performance. Low-quality fuel: Increases consumption by 3-8% due to incomplete combustion, Clogs the fuel system, Reduces engine power, Increases the risk of breakdowns. High quality fuel: Ensures optimal combustion, Keeps the system clean, Delivers the stated power, Reduces the risk of malfunctions. It is recommended to use fuel of the octane number recommended by the manufacturer (AI-92, AI-95, AI-98) from proven gas stations.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption per 1 km?
faqItems.a: Consumption per 1 km is calculated: Consumption per 1 km (l) = Consumption per 100 km / 100. Example: consumption 8.5 l/100km: Consumption per 1 km = 8.5 / 100 = 0.085 l/km. This is convenient for calculating short trips. For a 20 km trip: Fuel = 0.085 × 20 = 1.7 l. You can also calculate the cost of 1 km: Cost of 1 km = (Consumption per 1 km × Price per liter). With a consumption of 0.085 l/km and a price of 55 ₽/l: Cost = 0.085 × 55 = 4.68 ₽/km.

faqItems.q: What affects fuel consumption the most?
faqItems.a: The greatest influence on consumption is exerted by: 1) Driving style (sharp acceleration and braking increases consumption by 20-40%), 2) Driving speed (optimal 80-90 km/h, above 120 km/h consumption increases sharply), 3) Tire pressure (reduced pressure increases consumption by 3-5%), 4) Car load (every 100 kg increases consumption by 0.5-1 l/100km), 5) Traffic jams and frequent stops (increase consumption by 30-50%), 6) Use of air conditioning (increases consumption by 5-15%), 7) Technical condition (dirty filters, wear of spark plugs increase consumption by 10-20%).

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a truck?
faqItems.a: The calculation for a truck is similar to a car, but the consumption is much higher. Average truck consumption: Light trucks (up to 3.5 tons): 10-15 l/100km. Medium trucks (3.5-7.5 t): 15-25 l/100km. Heavy trucks (7.5-20 t): 25-40 l/100km. Consumption depends on the load: an empty truck consumes less, a loaded truck consumes more. The formula is the same: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100. For a truck, it is important to take into account the additional consumption when loading: +10-30% depending on the weight of the cargo.

faqItems.q: How long can you drive on a full tank?
faqItems.a: Depends on tank volume and flow rate. Formula: Distance = (Tank volume / Consumption) × 100. Examples: Tank 45 l, consumption 7 l/100 km: Distance = (45 / 7) × 100 = 643 km. Tank 60 l, consumption 9 l/100 km: Distance = (60 / 9) × 100 = 667 km. Tank 70 l, consumption 12 l/100 km: Distance = (70 / 12) × 100 = 583 km. Tank 93 l, consumption 15 l/100 km: Distance = (93 / 15) × 100 = 620 km. It is recommended not to lower the level below 1/4 tank to protect the fuel pump.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption taking into account traffic jams?
faqItems.a: In traffic jams, consumption increases by 30-100% due to frequent stops and accelerations. To account for traffic jams: 1) Calculate the base consumption for the city, 2) Estimate the time in traffic jams (for example, 30% of the trip), 3) Add the traffic factor: Consumption with traffic jams = Base consumption × (1 + Traffic jam coefficient). Odds: Light traffic jams (30% of the time): +10-20%. Average traffic jams (50% of the time): +30-50%. Heavy traffic jams (70% of the time): +50-100%. Example: base consumption 10 l/100km, average traffic jams: Consumption = 10 × 1.4 = 14 l/100km.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between the consumption of gasoline and diesel?
faqItems.a: Diesel engines are 20-35% more economical than gasoline engines with the same volume. Reasons: Diesel has a higher energy intensity (more energy per liter), Diesel engines run on a leaner mixture, Diesel has a higher efficiency (up to 45% vs 30% for gasoline). Example: 2.0 l petrol engine: consumption 9-11 l/100km. Diesel 2.0 l: consumption 6-8 l/100km. Difference per 1000 km: Gasoline: 100 l, Diesel: 70 l. Savings: 30 l or ~1650 ₽ at a price of 55 ₽/l. However, diesel fuel is usually 3-5 ₽/l more expensive than gasoline, which partially compensates for the savings.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a month?
faqItems.a: Calculation of monthly consumption: 1) Find out the average monthly mileage (for example, 2000 km), 2) Find out the average consumption of your car (for example, 9 l/100km), 3) Calculate: Monthly consumption = (Mileage × Consumption) / 100. Example: mileage 2000 km, consumption 9 l/100km: Monthly consumption = (2000 × 9) / 100 = 180 l. Monthly cost = 180 × 55 = 9900 ₽. For an accurate calculation, keep a log of refueling and mileage, sum up the volume of refueling for the month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a year?
faqItems.a: Annual consumption is calculated similarly to monthly: Annual consumption = (Annual mileage × Consumption) / 100. Average annual mileage of a passenger car: 15,000-20,000 km. Example: mileage 18,000 km/year, consumption 9 l/100 km: Annual consumption = (18,000 × 9) / 100 = 1,620 l. Annual cost = 1620 × 55 = 89100 ₽. For an accurate calculation: Record the mileage at the beginning of the year, Record the mileage at the end of the year, Calculate the difference, Apply the formula with your average consumption, Sum up all gas stations for the year.

faqItems.q: What is the fuel consumption of a hybrid car?
faqItems.a: Hybrid cars have a consumption of 4-6 l/100 km thanks to the combination of an internal combustion engine and an electric motor. Operating principle: At start and low speeds, the electric motor operates (flow = 0), At medium speeds, the internal combustion engine operates with optimal efficiency, During acceleration, both engines work together, During braking, energy is recovered into the battery. Examples of hybrid consumption: Toyota Prius: 3.8-4.5 l/100km (WLTP mixed), Lexus ES 300h: 4.5-5.2 l/100km, Honda Insight: 4.2-5.0 l/100km. Consumption depends on the mode of use: mainly city - 4-5 l/100km, mainly highway - 5-6 l/100km.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a motorcycle?
faqItems.a: The calculation for a motorcycle is similar to a car. Average consumption of motorcycles: Mopeds and scooters (50-150 cc): 2-3 l/100km. Light motorcycles (150-400 cc): 3-5 l/100km. Medium motorcycles (400-750 cc): 4-7 l/100km. Sports motorcycles (750-1000+ cc): 6-10 l/100km. Cruisers (large): 7-12 l/100km. Formula: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100. Example: motorcycle with a consumption of 5 l/100 km, trip 300 km: Fuel = (5 × 300) / 100 = 15 l. A motorcycle tank is usually 12-20 liters; on a full tank you can travel 240-400 km.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption with a trailer?
faqItems.a: A trailer increases consumption by 15-30% depending on weight and size. Calculation: Base consumption without trailer (e.g. 9 l/100km), Trailer coefficient: Light trailer (up to 500 kg): +15-20%, Medium trailer (500-1000 kg): +20-25%, Heavy trailer (1000+ kg): +25-30%. Consumption with trailer = Base consumption × (1 + Coefficient). Example: base consumption 9 l/100km, average trailer 700 kg: Consumption = 9 × 1.225 = 11.025 l/100km. For a 500 km trip: Fuel = (11.025 × 500) / 100 = 55.125 l (without trailer it would be 45 l).

faqItems.q: How to save fuel in traffic jams?
faqItems.a: Ways to save money in traffic jams: 1) Do not warm up the engine for a long time - 30-60 seconds is enough, immediately start moving smoothly, 2) Accelerate and brake smoothly, avoid sudden maneuvers, 3) Maintain a constant speed, use coasting (driving in neutral in safe areas), 4) Turn off the air conditioning at low temperatures, 5) Close the windows at high speeds - open windows increase resistance, 6) Plan routes, avoiding peak hours, 7) Use a navigator with traffic information, 8) Do not overload the car, 9) Monitor the tire pressure.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for gas equipment (GBO)?
faqItems.a: HBO uses gas (propane-butane) instead of gasoline. Gas consumption is usually 10-20% higher than gasoline consumption due to lower energy consumption. Calculation: Gasoline consumption (for example, 10 l/100km), Gas consumption = Gasoline × 1.15 = 11.5 l/100km, Cost: With the price of gasoline 55 ₽/l and gas 28 ₽/l: Gasoline: 10 × 55 = 550 ₽/100km, Gas: 11.5 × 28 = 322 ₽/100 km. Savings: 550 - 322 = 228 ₽/100 km (41% savings). For 20,000 km/year savings: 45,600 ₽. The formula is the same: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100, but use gas consumption.

faqItems.q: Does the time of year affect fuel consumption?
faqItems.a: Yes, the time of year affects consumption: Winter: Increase in consumption by 10-20% due to warming up the engine, Using the stove, Reducing tire pressure due to cold, Slippery roads (slipping). Summer: Increase in consumption by 5-15% due to the use of air conditioning, Increased air temperature (less dense air), Traffic jams due to holidays. Spring/Autumn: Optimal conditions, minimum consumption. Recommendation: When planning your trips, take into account seasonal factors, adding 10-15% to the calculation in winter and summer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption when driving in the mountains?
faqItems.a: Driving in the mountains increases consumption by 20-50% due to climbs. Calculation: Base consumption (for example, 9 l/100km), Mountain coefficient: Easy climbs (slope up to 5%): +15-20%, Medium climbs (slope 5-10%): +25-35%, Steep climbs (slope 10%+): +40-50%. Mountain flow = Base flow × (1 + Coefficient). Example: base consumption 9 l/100km, average climbs: Consumption = 9 × 1.3 = 11.7 l/100km. When descending, consumption may be minimal (coasting), but with frequent braking, consumption increases. For mountainous areas, it is better to calculate the consumption separately for ascents and descents.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for engine idling?
faqItems.a: At idle, the engine consumes 0.5-2 l/hour, depending on the size and type of engine. Calculation: Hourly consumption × Operating hours = Fuel volume. Examples: Small car (1.4 l): 0.5-0.8 l/hour, Middle class (2.0 l): 0.8-1.2 l/hour, SUV (3.5 l): 1.5-2.0 l/hour. Example: an SUV sits idle for 2 hours: Consumption = 1.75 × 2 = 3.5 l. For a month of sitting in traffic jams for 30 minutes a day (15 hours): Consumption = 1.75 × 15 = 26.25 liters. Cost = 26.25 × 55 = 1444 ₽. Recommendation: When stopping for more than 2 minutes, it is better to turn off the engine to save money.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption taking into account the quality of the road?
faqItems.a: The quality of the road affects the consumption: Asphalt (good condition): Basic consumption. Asphalt (poor condition): +5-10% due to shaking and loss of speed. Gravel: +10-20% due to increased resistance. Dirt road: +20-40% due to low speed and slippage. Calculation: Base flow × Road coefficient. Example: base consumption 9 l/100 km, trip 200 km on asphalt and 100 km on dirt: Asphalt: (9 × 200) / 100 = 18 l, Ground: (9 × 1.3 × 100) / 100 = 11.7 l, Total: 29.7 l. For an accurate calculation, divide the route by type of road and calculate each section separately.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a car with an automatic transmission?
faqItems.a: An automatic transmission increases consumption by 5-15% compared to a manual transmission due to losses in the torque converter. Calculation: Basic consumption (for manual transmission), Automatic transmission consumption = Basic × 1.1 (average coefficient). Example: manual transmission consumption 8 l/100km, automatic transmission: Consumption = 8 × 1.1 = 8.8 l/100km. Modern automatic transmissions (variators, robots) have lower losses and consumption is closer to a manual transmission. When calculating, use the actual fuel consumption of your car with an automatic transmission, and do not try to recalculate with a manual transmission. The formula for calculating fuel is the same: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption when towing another car?
faqItems.a: Towing significantly increases fuel consumption by 40-80% depending on the weight of the vehicle being towed. Calculation: Base fuel consumption of your car, Towing ratio: Light car (up to 1200 kg): +40-50%, Medium car (1200-1600 kg): +50-70%, Heavy car (1600+ kg): +70-80%. Towing consumption = Base × (1 + Factor). Example: base consumption 10 l/100km, towing an average car: Consumption = 10 × 1.6 = 16 l/100km. For a 200 km trip: Fuel = (16 × 200) / 100 = 32 L (without towing it would be 20 L). It is recommended to use a tow truck for long distances.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for an old car?
faqItems.a: An older car typically uses 10-30% more than a new one due to engine wear, reduced efficiency, and general wear and tear. Calculation: Consumption of a new car (from the passport), Wear rate: Car 5-10 years: +10-15%, Car 10-15 years: +15-25%, Car 15+ years: +25-30%. Real consumption = Passport × (1 + Coefficient). Example: passport consumption is 8 l/100 km, the car is 12 years old: Real consumption = 8 × 1.2 = 9.6 l/100 km. For an accurate calculation, it is better to measure the actual consumption using the filling method, rather than using passport data. Regular maintenance helps keep consumption closer to normal.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption taking into account wind?
faqItems.a: Wind affects consumption: Tailwind (at the back): Reduces consumption by 5-15% at high speed. Headwind (head-on): Increases consumption by 10-25% at high speed. Crosswind: Increases flow rate by 5-10% due to course corrections. At low speeds (up to 60 km/h) the influence of wind is minimal. Calculation: Base flow × Wind coefficient. Example: base consumption 9 l/100km, strong headwind: Consumption = 9 × 1.2 = 10.8 l/100km. For an accurate calculation, take into account weather conditions and plan with a margin of 10-15% in unfavorable conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a carburetor engine?
faqItems.a: Carburetor engines usually consume 10-20% more than injection engines due to less accurate fuel delivery. The calculation is similar to injection, but use the actual consumption of your carburetor car. Formula: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100. Average carburetor consumption: Small cars (VAZ 2107, 2109): 8-10 l/100km, Middle class (VAZ 2110, 2114): 9-12 l/100km. To reduce consumption: Regularly clean and adjust the carburetor, Change the air filter, Use high-quality fuel, Check the ignition. Modern carburetor systems can be economical if properly tuned.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a turbocharged car?
faqItems.a: Turbocharging increases power, but can increase consumption by 5-15% during aggressive driving due to higher fuel consumption. During quiet driving, consumption can be even lower due to efficient combustion. The calculation uses the actual fuel consumption of your turbocharged car. Formula: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100. Examples of turbo engine consumption: 1.4 TSI (Volkswagen): 6-8 l/100km (economical driving), 2.0 TSI: 8-11 l/100km. To save money: Avoid sudden acceleration (the turbine consumes more fuel), Use high-quality fuel (turbo engines are demanding), Maintain the system regularly (the turbine requires high-quality oil).

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption when using all-wheel drive (4WD)?
faqItems.a: All-wheel drive increases fuel consumption by 15-25% compared to front- or rear-wheel drive due to losses in the transfer case and additional weight. Calculation: Basic consumption (for 2WD), 4WD consumption = Basic × 1.2 (average coefficient). Example: 2WD consumption 9 l/100km, 4WD: Consumption = 9 × 1.2 = 10.8 l/100km. When traveling 500 km: Fuel = (10.8 × 500) / 100 = 54 l (without 4WD it would be 45 l). Modern all-wheel drive systems (automatic engagement) can reduce consumption under normal conditions by engaging all-wheel drive only when necessary. For an accurate calculation, use the actual fuel consumption of your 4WD vehicle.

faqItems.q: How to calculate how much money is spent on fuel per month?
faqItems.a: Calculation of monthly costs: 1) Find out the monthly mileage (for example, 2000 km), 2) Find out the average consumption (for example, 9 l / 100 km), 3) Calculate the monthly fuel consumption: Consumption = (Mileage × Consumption) / 100, 4) Multiply by the price per liter: Cost = Consumption × Price. Example: mileage 2000 km, consumption 9 l/100 km, price 55 ₽/l: Consumption = (2000 × 9) / 100 = 180 l, Cost = 180 × 55 = 9900 ₽/month. For an accurate calculation, keep a journal of refills: Sum up all refills for the month, Sum up all expenses, Get the exact amount. You can also calculate the cost of 1 km: Cost of 1 km = (Consumption per 1 km × Price) = (0.09 × 55) = 4.95 RUR/km, then multiply by mileage.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fuel consumption for a car with LPG (gas equipment)?
faqItems.a: LPG (liquefied gas) consumes 15-25% more than gasoline, but costs 2 times less. Calculation: Gasoline consumption (for example, 10 l/100 km), Gas consumption = Gasoline × 1.2 = 12 l/100 km, Cost: With the price of gasoline 55 ₽/l and gas 28 ₽/l: Gasoline: 10 × 55 = 550 ₽/100 km, Gas: 12 × 28 = 336 ₽/100 km. Savings: 550 - 336 = 214 ₽/100 km (39% savings). For 20,000 km/year: Savings = 42,800 ₽. The formula for calculating fuel is the same: Fuel = (Consumption × Distance) / 100, but use gas consumption. Example: trip 600 km, gas consumption 12 l/100 km: Fuel = (12 × 600) / 100 = 72 l of gas.

overview.title: Customs duties calculator for calculating customs clearance of a car
overview.content: An online customs duties calculator will help you accurately calculate the cost of customs clearance of a car when importing it into Russia. The calculator takes into account all mandatory payments: customs duty, excise duty, VAT and recycling fee, depending on the cost, engine size, age and fuel type of the car.
overview.additionalContent: Customs clearance of a car is a mandatory procedure when importing a vehicle into Russia. Knowing the exact cost of customs clearance helps you plan your budget, choose the best car for import and avoid unexpected expenses. The calculator uses current tariffs and rates approved by the Eurasian Economic Union.
